canadian | austrian

node.text: Watch me struggle showing you how I pack my backcountry camping backpack. This would be for 2 nights in the mountains (bear canister is packed in)

node.title: How to Pack a Backcountry Camping Backpack

node.text: A coffee chat with @missholldoll and I about venturing into the backcountry, our must have items, safety and even the best backcountry meals.

node.title: Live with @missholldoll - Solo Backpacking and Hiking Questions

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrea Ference on August 17, 2021 tagging @vagabondhearts, @sonos, and @mikesugianto. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

node.text:
What would be the first song on a playlist of your favourite memory in the outdoors?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
This summer @sonos asked me just that - to build a playlist that brought me back to this morning, sitting in the heart of Bugaboo Provincial Park. The feeling of being surrounded by towering granite walls decorated with glaciers tens of thousands of years old having my first sip of coffee. Check it out via the link in my bio and let me know how you think I did!
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
This playlist was created in partnership with the launch of the @Sonos Roam, a portable and ultra-durable speaker that has been accompanying me on adventures big and small this summer. From listening to true crime podcasts in the tent, to hanging out on pizza shaped pool floaties in the middle of glacial lakes (it is waterproof, I can confirm) the @Sonos Roam made sure I had the ultimate soundtrack with me wherever I went . Hoping this playlist hits all the right feelings during that sunrise coffee in the mountains. #sonospartner #sonosroam

node.text:
You have one week in the Canadian Rockies - what is at the top of your to-do list?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I am currently sitting on the tarmac waiting for a plane to take me back home. It’s been selfishly nice the last few summers without tourists in the rockies - a little more space in the parking lots, a lot less garbage along the trails. But as I have said before… I really do miss watching people see this beautiful backyard of mine for the first time. Seeing eyes wide as the morning sun kisses the ten peaks, overhearing conversations questioning how we manage to keep each of our a lakes different (but equally awe inspiring) shade of green and blue and knowing that, for so many, this may be the only time they ever get to be face to face with a glacier or the northern lights. A constant reminder not to take this home of mine for granted.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
So, welcome back! And as you pack your bags please take a minute to brush up on your LNT principals. Also if you see me on the trails over the next few weeks - please say hi!
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
Hopefully the comments section below can provide some help in your planning… but a few personal favourites for keeping you fueled while you’re here:
•Rusticana in Canmore - the best cinnamon buns 
• @eclipsecoffeeroasters in Canmore - coffee
• @thecommunitea in Canmore - get the rainbow pad thai
•Afternoon Tea at the @fairmontbanff (book ahead)
• @sunhousejasper in Jasper - coffee
• @reposados_tacos_golden in Golden - great burritos
• @wanderingferncafe pop up in Golden - the best oat milk latte I’ve ever had
•Fuze in Invermere - the butter chicken is *chefs kiss*

node.text:
I get the most intense cravings whenever I am out hiking. Normally for fresh vegetables, fruits or a really cold can of sparkling water. But most of last summer all that I wanted (but kept on forgetting to pack) was a classic pb&j. And not even a good one - I am talking the kind you find at the bottom of a second grader’s backpack on a Friday afternoon, squished and warm and oozing its contents all over the bag tasked with containing it.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I also never have these cravings until I am several hours from the trailhead, a few hundred km from home. But the night before this late September hike I finally remembered. And although not nearly warm or old or squished enough, it was everything I had hoped and dreamed of all summer long. A hot late season day with a classic pb&j at the top of a mountain along an iconic glacier.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
What is your biggest backcountry craving?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrea Ference on August 10, 2021 tagging @vagabondhearts, and @mikesugianto. May be an image of 1 person and nature.
Photo shared by Andrea Ference on August 10, 2021 tagging @dannerboots, and @glyder. May be an image of one or more people and nature.
Photo by Andrea Ference on August 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.
Photo shared by Andrea Ference on August 08, 2021 tagging @lululemon, @dannerboots, @vagabondhearts, @mikesugianto, and @sweatybetty. May be an image of 1 person, nature and mountain.

node.text:
What is the last thing that you crossed off your bucket list?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I hiked to the base of this mountain for the first time three summers ago. With three friends, for three nights. Standing atop was not in the cards for that trip, I was unprepared and it was never the plan. But when I returned last year it was. And it didn’t happen. And so, a few months later when the larch needles turned from soft green to a brittle amber, we one again went back and once again I did not climb (technically, scramble) it’s crumbly scree slopes. But finally, a few weeks ago, on my fourth trip hauling all of my gear into the same middle of nowhere, I made it up to the top just in time for one of my favourite sunsets with a few of my favourite people. It was cold as the sun dipped below the neighbouring peaks and the smoke was steadily rolling in after a few days of pure luck and clear skies. There is nothing particularly special about this mountain, it isn’t Everest or Logan, hardly the tallest in even a few km range. But, for me, it sat idly in the back of my mind for years - a nagging curiosity of what the world looked like from its rocky summit.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrea Ference on August 08, 2021 tagging @lululemon, @dannerboots, @vagabondhearts, @mikesugianto, and @sweatybetty. May be an image of 1 person, nature and mountain.
Photo by Andrea Ference on August 08, 2021. May be an image of nature and mountain.
Photo by Andrea Ference on August 08, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by Andrea Ference on August 08, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by Andrea Ference in Purcell Mountains with @vagabondhearts, @mikesugianto, and @sweatybetty. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
These days we have too many choices and too little time. Maybe that is why I run away to the mountains so often - to simplify the decisions I need to make. Hot chocolate or apple cider before bed. Head out for a sunrise hike or make coffee by the lake at camp. The decisions are simple and inconsequential. It is also why I started to streamline my wardrobe. Packing a handful of super functional items that can all be worn together interchangeably. I am not yet at the single black turtleneck stage of minamlasim but slowly making my way there. 
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
My summer @sweatybetty capsule wardrobe:

Power 7/8 Gym Leggings - Steel Blue
Circuit Zip-Up Sports Bra - Blue Floral Splash Print
Power 6" Cycling Shorts - Black 
After Class Crop Sweatshirt - Mirage Green
On Your Marks 4” Running Shorts - Black
@teva Original Universal Sandal - White
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
And remember, use my code “sbvagabond20” for 20% off of all full priced purchases at sweatybetty.com #iamasweatybetty

node.text:
Would you rather… hike up a mountain or swim in a glacial lake?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
We spent sunset atop the summit behind me, 3km(1.8mi) with 1,050m (3,500ft) of gain - short but not so sweet. Hiked out by headlamp, got lost in the forest and tucked into our tents well after midnight. The plan was to sleep through sunrise but with calm water and sore muscles I opted for a dip in the lake. It was not warm but 10/10 would not change a thing.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
2021.07.18
British Columbia, Canada
 ⠀ ⠀ ⠀
#camp #glacier #summer #canada #backcountrycamping #swim #glaciallake #polarplunge #reels 

🎥 @mikesugianto

node.text:
Do your parents still worry about you venturing out into the backcountry alone?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
One of my most often asked questions and the only I can’t really answer for myself. So last week, in partnership with @REI I took my mom deep into the mountains and asked her just that. She was who I spent my first night in the backcountry with all of those years ago. On the floor of the Grand Canyon with all borrowed gear, two hired guides and no idea what the heck we were doing. We curled up in sleeping bags atop inflatable mattresses for the first time under a cloudless sky (no need for a tent fly) in awe of the sheer volume of stars. That was where it all started for me. A springboard into what has since become my career and my greatest passion and the space in which I feel most myself. #REIPartner
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
As for her answer, I gave Erna 15 seconds to answer and this is what she had to say: “I used to get worried about Andrea, but now I’ve been out hiking with her and know that she’s totally prepared and really knows what she’s doing. She’s always aware of her surroundings so I am not longer too worried”
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
My biggest pieces of advice for anyone who is hoping to ease their loved ones’ minds as they head out in the backcountry (alone or not):
1. Know what you are doing (for me this means taking classes - @REI offers a ton, and researching anything I don’t know) and ask a lot of questions.
2. Pick up a satellite phone to check in with them while you’re off the grid (I use the @garminoutdoor inReach mini)
3. If you’re able - Take them with you, be their guide, pack food and plan a route and show them that you can not only take care of yourself but can show them a good time too!

node.text:
What is the one (cheat) item you bring camping with you?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I started packing ramen for breakfast a handful of years ago. It takes up way too much space in the bear bin, is a pain in the but too clean up after and, salt content aside, hold no real nutritional value. But I have never much enjoyed breakfast foods and at home am a regular intermittent faster - so this is how I get my pre-hike calories in. Hot, salty, sometimes a little too spicy, soup.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
Some of my other bonus items: cans of sparkling water, a camp pillow that is both down and inflatable, sour patch kids, my swimsuit and towel, a @silkelondon sleep cap, earplugs for when I share a tent with @mikesugianto aaaaaand a @thermarest seat pad.

node.text:
With summer in full swing how are you keeping cool?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
Lately I have been (polar plunges aside) reaching for my @lairdsuperfood hydrate to keep me from overheating on backcountry hikes and city runs. As a coconut water lover this drink mix has the same great taste and is high in calcium, magnesium, potassium and iron with no added sugars. Hydrate is also under a dollar a serving and comes in four flavours (mango pineapple is my current go-to). Oh, and far more sustainable than any other coconut water available with 19 servings per container (I normally pop a few scoops in a reusable silicone bag for a weekend away). #LSFpartner
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
2021.07.10
Bugaboo Provincial Park, British Columbia, Canada
 ⠀ ⠀ ⠀
#camp #glacier #summer #canada #backcountrycamping #lovemylondre #polarplunge #reels

node.text:
Combining passions in Big Sur, California.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
My (car) camping coffee recipe:
* Two (generous) scoops of coffee beans ground for chemex (coffee shops can grind to whatever brewing method you use) - I got this amount by weighing how many scoops I needed for ~50g at home and replicating it here.
* I aim to have my water at 200-205°F (10° or so below boiling)- for this I boiled water in a pot and then transferred it into my little kettle. It worked like a charm!
* Wet the filter, empty the chemex, add in the coffee grounds.
* Pour in enough water that the grounds are all wet, watch it bloom (bubbles should come up) for 30-60 seconds
* Add in the rest of your water. I pull the filter out when the water hits the little bump on the chemex (~650g)
* Pop a stroopwaffle on top and enjoy!
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
How do you like your coffee? Let me know if you have any questions!

node.text:
I used to think that the “better” (read : more experienced) I became at traveling in the alpine the more self reliant I would become and therefore the less gear i would require. Oh how naïve I was. In reality, the inverse has proven to be true. It started with this helmet - I realized that it was not enough to get to the trailhead extra early and scramble only with people I know to yell “rock” conservatively. That wind and animals and the subtle shifting of the earth (not to mention groups ascending during our descent) can all cause rocks to fall - and it was no longer worth the risk. As I sit at my kitchen table this morning slowly unpacking and letting the 50lbs of gear I hauled into the mountains this weekend air out/dry I cant help but think of the days I used to run through avalanche terrain and slide down glaciers without a care in the world. Ignorant bliss and a whole lot of luck I guess.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
These days my legs shake and I need a little self pep talk before stepping into moderate terrain - even with all of the gear and knowledge that the past half decade has provided me. The more time I spend in the mountains the more I want to see and the more terrified I am of them.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
And yes, on hot summer days I will opt to hike in shorts and sports bras (lathered in sunscreen) - but I promise in that backpack of mine resides a handful of layers and everything I need to survive a night stranded in the alpine (and my @garminoutdoor inReach so hopefully I wont need to).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrea Ference on July 15, 2021 tagging @vagabondhearts, and @mikesugianto. May be an image of one or more people and nature.

node.text:
A reminder today that there are so many people from your past who know only a version of you that no longer exists.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
The other day, in the most misogynist and condescending of ways, a distant family member I had all but forgotten referred to me as a princess. It was in response to me correcting their inappropriate behaviour toward a medical professional tasked with my grandmother’s care. And for a fraction of second he made me feel small - and then my blood began to boil and my body tensed and instead of going with my gut instinct to defend myself - I simply left the group chat. There was nothing of value for me in there anyways and his mind was not worth changing. He spoke to me in the way that he would have 25+ years ago, possibly the last time we interacted, when I wore nothing but pink frilly dresses and clung to my daddy’s hand for dear life. But in that quarter century I have changed. He chose a simpler, easier life and while there is nothing wrong with that - I didn’t. I choose the path of most resistance, packed my bags and moved across the country to study politics and neuroscience, regularly carry half my bodyweight in gear and haul it up mountains to spend weeks alone. I have traveled around the world several times over learned new languages, rode camels in Egypt and saw the sun rise over the Taj Mahal in India, I have slept under the stars in the Andes and the Alps and at the bottom of the Grand Canyon. I run marathons and swim with sharks and walk on ice tens of thousands of years old. I have built a business from the ground up… and I have done all of these things and more… on my own.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I once was a princess, the only girl with too many brothers and maybe just a little bit of a daddy’s girl. But that, my friends, was a long time ago. There will aways be people clinging to past versions of you like a security blanket, they will use it to make you feel small, to control you, to belittle you. Don’t let them. Embrace that you have grown past the person you once were and past the people who refuse to acknowledge and celebrate your progress.
